description: Borrowed from Middle French facile, from Latin facilis (“easy to do, easy, doable”), from faciō (“I do, make”). Compare Spanish fácil (“easy”).

adjectives.description: facile (comparative more facile, superlative most facile)

entries.meaning: Easy, now especially in a disparaging sense; contemptibly easy. [from 15th c.]
examples: as he that is benumbed with cold sits shaking, that might relieve himself with a little exercise or stirring, do they complain, but will not use the facile and ready means to do themselves good […].

entries.meaning: (now rare) Amiable, flexible, easy to get along with. [from 16th c.]
examples: His facile disposition made him many friends.

entries.meaning: Effortless, fluent (of work, abilities etc.). [from 17th c.]
examples: we can learn the impression that he made upon a stranger and a foreigner at this period, thanks to the facile pen of Fannu Burney.

entries.meaning: Lazy, simplistic (especially of explanations, discussions etc.). [from 19th c.]
examples: There is a facile view that our green commitments – to tackling climate change, avoiding air and water pollution, protecting natural habitats – are an obstacle to growth. The message of the commodity markets is surely different.

entries.meaning: (chemistry) Of a reaction or other process, taking place readily.
examples: Decarboxylation of beta-keto acids is facile...
